subject: Translation Message improvements
commit_message:
Translation Message improvements

The improvements to the current Message implementation include:

* Implementing a new method translate() to explicitely perform the
translation of a Message object, instead of relying on setting the
'locale' property.
* All of the codebase assumes _() is a unicode object, so make the
Message unicode, that will always behave as unicode, except for the fact
that it has the extra ability to translate() on demand.
* Remove the internal representation of the translated Message (i.e. the
data property) and rely on parent implementations.
* Enhancement to the corresponding TestTranslation class to enable fake
translations for multiple locales.

With this patch the REST API translation in the other projects will work
with very minimal or no impact after re-enabling the 'lazy' _().

subject: Add an option for ignoring h302 for some names
commit_message:
Add an option for ignoring h302 for some names

The H302 rule, allowing only importing of modules, is generally very
useful and helpful, but there are many places where it makes sense to
break it, due to convention and better readability. One such instance
is django.conf.settings, which is traditionally imported as:

    from django.conf import settings

but there are other such cases (gettext's _ comes to mind). Up until
now, we dealt with those cases by simply adding a #noqa comment. This
solution is, however, suboptimal, as it also silences all other
warnings, in particular ones about unused imports and alphabetic order
of imports.

This change adds a "h302_exceptions" option to the configuration of
Hacking, which allows us to list the names that are allowed to be
imported, even when they are not modules.

This will let us remove a lot of of "#noqa" from our code.

and POST requests is treated in a similar way to user
metadata. System metadata is not yet supported for
object requests.

Secondly, changes in the proxy controllers ensure that
headers in the system metadata namespace will pass through
in requests to backend servers. A convenience function
(swift.common.request_helpers.add_sys_meta) is provided
for middleware to add system metadata to a request, and
as a heads-up to developers that the reserved namespace
exists.

Thirdly, system metadata returned from backend servers
in GET or HEAD responses is added to the cached info
dict, which middleware can access.

Finally, a gatekeeper middleware module is provided
which filters all system metadata headers from requests
and responses by removing headers with names starting
x-account-sysmeta-, x-container-sysmeta-. The gatekeeper
also removes headers starting x-object-sysmeta- in
anticipation of future support for system metadata being
set for objects. This prevents clients from writing or
reading system metadata.

The required_filters list in swift/proxy/server.py is
modified to include the gatekeeper middleware so that
the gatekeeper will be automatically inserted close to
the start of the pipeline if it has not been configured.

subject: Replace Simple/Chance Scheduler with FilterScheduler
commit_message:
Replace Simple/Chance Scheduler with FilterScheduler

This patch replaces SimpleScheduler and ChanceScheduler with
FilterScheduler. Scheduler manager is changed so that when it
detects 'scheduler_driver' is set to SimpleScheduler or
ChanceScheduler, it changes underlying scheduler driver to
FilterScheduler, and then host manager will use a pre-defined
combination of filters & weighers to keep scheduler behavior *MOSTLY*
the same as its old counterparts.

To simulate ChanceScheduler/SimpleScheduler, 'AvailabilityZoneFilter',
'CapacityFilter' and 'CapabilitiesFilter' are chosen to filter
out hosts that isn't in the target AZ, doesn't have sufficient
capacity and doesn't support needed capabilities. And newly
added 'ChanceWeigher' will randomly pick a host from hosts
that passes above filters - just like ChanceScheduler does;
for SimpleScheduler, 'AllocatedCapacityWeigher' will sort hosts
with their 'allocated_capacity' - the one allocates the least
is the winner by default.

So the two new weigher, 'ChanceWeigher' and 'AllocatedCapacityWeigher'
are the key FilterScheduler to act identical when choosing
back-ends to serve requests. The 3 filters on the other hand,
are essential to make sure this 'new' Simple/Chance Scheduler can
support volume types, encryption and QoS.

commit_message:
Only retry once on non-resource manager exception

Currently we retry on all types of exceptions. This means it can take a
long time for an error to occur three times. However, for transient
errors, it is very helpful to at least retry the server build once.

However, we still get build failures due to scheduler races, so it would
be good to increase the number of retries for scheduler races.

This change looks at a compromise where if a non-resource manager
related exception occurs, only one retry is attempted, but for resource
manager exceptions we retry up to scheduler_max_attempts.

This change also increases the default max_attmepts to 10 from 3.

There is currently no useful developer-focused documentation in-tree
for Neutron. There are a smattering of useful documents on the

instructions for using DevStack for OpenStack contribution/testing.

subject: Perform init() for each temporary user
commit_message:
Perform init() for each temporary user

The init() mechanism that allowed to allocate resources in the cloud like
servers or floating ips has been broken since the introduction of temporary
tenants and users used during benchmarking due to the fact that resources
created from, say, an admin account could not be accessed by temporary users.

This patch repairs the issue by changing the way init() methods work. Here,
we call init() once for each of the temporary users which enables to allocate
resources for each of the temporary users and makes them available for access
during benchmarking.

Finally, slight UT refactoring is present here which replaces with-blocks for
mocks with the more appropriate decorator syntax.

Blueprint test-engine-init
